etymologies: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French treisoun, from Latin traditio(n-) ‘handing over’, from the verb tradere

notes.text: Formerly, there were two types of crime to which the term treason was applied: petty treason (the crime of murdering one's master) and high treason (the crime of betraying one's country). As a classification of offense, the crime of petty treason was abolished in 1828. In modern use, the term high treason is now often simply called treason

definitions: the crime of betraying one's country, especially by attempting to kill the sovereign or overthrow the government
the action of betraying someone or something

examples.text: doubt is the ultimate treason against faith

shortDefinitions: action of betraying person or thing

definitions: the crime of murdering someone to whom the murderer owed allegiance, such as a master or husband.
shortDefinitions: crime of murdering someone to whom murderer owed allegiance
